column1: Kyphosis can occur at any age, although it is rare at birth.
It is caused by the wedging together of several bones of the spine (vertebrae) in a row.

In adults, kyphosis can be caused by: - Degenerative diseases of the spine (such as arthritis or disk degeneration) - Fractures caused by osteoporosis (osteoporotic compression fractures) - Injury (trauma) - Slipping of one vertebra forward on another (spondylolisthesis) Other causes of kyphosis include: - Certain endocrine diseases - Connective tissue disorders - Infection (such as tuberculosis) - Muscular dystrophy - Neurofibromatosis - Paget disease - PolioScoliosis - Spina bifida - Tumors
Symptoms may include any of the following: - Difficulty breathing (in severe cases) - Fatigue - Mild back pain - Round back appearance - Tenderness and stiffness in the spine
Treatment depends on the cause of the disorder: - Congenital kyphosis requires corrective surgery at an early age.
- Scheuermann disease is treated with a brace and physical therapy.
If the kyphosis is due to degenerative joint disease or multiple compression fractures, surgery is needed to correct the defect and improve pain.
Treating and preventing osteoporosis can prevent many cases of kyphosis in the elderly.
